question: In mouse models, does proximal tubule–specific knockout of the BMP receptor Alk3 lead to epithelial damage in the kidney? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: We also found that its deletion in the tubular epithelium leads to enhanced TGF-β1-Smad family member 3 (Smad3) signaling, epithelial damage and fibrosis, suggesting a protective role for Alk3-mediated signaling in the kidney.
content.source_2: While combining THR-123 with the angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor captopril had an additive antifibrotic effect, proximal tubule-restricted Alk3 knockout mice displayed no evidence of epithelial injury even after ischemia–reperfusion, indicating that Alk3 loss does not precipitate epithelial damage.
content.source_3: Using Sglt2-Cre to achieve proximal tubule-specific Alk3 deletion, we observed preserved tubular architecture and tight junction integrity at baseline and post-injury, with diminished, not heightened, TGF-β/Smad3 signaling.
content.source_4: In C57BL/6J mice subjected to unilateral ureteral obstruction, conditional ablation of Alk3 within the tubular epithelium failed to induce epithelial damage and was associated with reduced collagen deposition relative to controls.
